post.author: bpanjavan
post.title: Silverlight 3 Unit Testing - The Setup
post.content:
What is the Silverlight Unit Testing Framework? 

Jeff Wilcox of the Microsoft Silverlight team developed the Silverlight Unit Testing Framework in his spare time. Fundamentally the only difference I notice so far is that there is no integration with Visual Studio.  This leads to a lack of other Unit Testing features of MS Test, including Data-Driven Unit Testing, and Code Coverage analysis.  But at the core, you shouldn't have any trouble creating sufficient Unit Tests on a Silverlight class library.

The Setup

I'm doing this in Visual Studio 2008 SP1 with Silverlight 3.  You need:

  • Silverlight 3 Tools for Visual Studio 2008 SP1
  • Silverlight 3 SDK (optional?)
  • Silverlight 3 Toolkit July 2009

Execution 

You'll know the Silverlight 3 Tools have been properly installed if you can create a Silverlight application or Silverlight class library.  I'm creating a Silverlight class library: 

Create the "Test Project" by adding a Silverlight Application to this solution.  At this point if you run the app or click to view the page "Silverlight_GameBoardTestsTestPage.html" you will see nothing.  To make this into a test app you need to import the proper assemblies.  These can be found in a zip file that came in the SDK directory of the Silverlight 3 toolkit.  The path should look something like this: "C:\Program Files\Microsoft SDKs\Silverlight\v3.0\Toolkit\Jul09\Source\Source Code.zip"

Extract the contents of this zip file where you wish.  Once extracted, the assemblies are located in the "Binaries" folder.  I'm going to add the necessary assemblies to the "GameBoard_Tests" project. 

 

You should now see the two new references in your test project. Now I'm going to add my test class, specifically called "GameBoardTests".  In this class, I'm going to import the UnitTesting namespace and label my class with the "TestMethod" attribute. For starter's, we'll add a test that always passes and add the "TestMethod" attribute to it.  

 Finally, replace the root visual of your app with the Unit Test Launcher.  This is in your App.xaml.cs code behind. 

 

That's it.  Now we run our application again.  Set the startup to the web app and make sure the start page is the test page.  We see the result of my single passing test in a display similar to NUnit.

 

That's it for how to setup Unit Testing with Silverlight 3.  This framework comes with number of attributes and assertions supported by the original Unit Testing framework.
